post.title: Unpopular opinion: conservatives should have complained about the butchering of our civil rights after 9/11 like they now do masks, instead of cheering it on for "fighting terrorism".

body:
We all collectively went mad for a while after 9/11. Everyone was so emotional that there were really only two thoughts in the "collective consciousness" of the nation: revenge and safety. Which was understandable. The issue was that our glorious leaders were allowed to draft legislation during that period of temporary insanity (and yeah, I think Dick Cheney is just evil and along with others there was certainly some nefarious intent behind the trashing of our rights). But while it was happening, most folks werent thinking about rights.  We were all too upset. When we woke up from it, a lot of conservatives wouldn't criticize it because it was "their guys" who enacted it. The same way you hear crickets on the left when you talk about Obama bombing civilians overseas. Its tribalism and pride. 

I think there should be a law about a "cooling off period" after a national disaster where they're not allowed to draft any new legislation until everyone calms down. 

So yeah. I agree witchu, but hindsight is 20/20 and at the time, very few people (myself included, though I wouldn't call myself a conservative) were able to master their emotions enough to really see it in the same way we see it now, 19 years later.

I think there should be a law about a "cooling off period" after a national disaster where they're not allowed to draft any new legislation until everyone calms down.

So yeah. I agree witchu, but hindsight is 20/20 and at the time, very few people (myself included, though I wouldn't call myself a conservative) were able to master their emotions enough to really see it in the same way we see it now, 19 years later.

body:
I left the Republican Party in 2001 for the twin unforgivable sins of the Patriot Act and the single-largest expansion of government both numerically and percentage-wise ever perpetrated upon the American People.

Absolute travesty what they did, with bi-partisan support, gutting the Constitution and bloating the government like that.

That was my wakeup call that every single one of those slimy fucks is out to get the American people, no matter whether there be a donkey or an elephant hanging on their office door, they're out for the destruction of the American Way of Life.

**edit**: added "of government".

body:
This is a very fair and accurate way to describe it. 

It is perhaps important to understand for those who were too young or not yet born at the time, nearly the entire nation was collectively in support of these actions at the time, even the public. You still hear people mentioning "post 9/11 unity" for a reason, literally the entire country as whole was looking the same direction, even politics were bipartisan and on the same page. 

Good case and point that supporting and passing legislation as an emotional reaction is not wise.

body:
Holy fucking shit, that "Saddam Hussein = Al Qaeda" meme that they pushed out back in 2001/2002 to try to legitimize a neo con regime change war in Iraq by linking Saddam Hussein to 9/11 is somehow still out there.

It really is remarkable.

body:
You took it on the chin for that comment, but I can see your point.

We're seeing now what happens when there are no restrictions or too few restrictions on liberties, with mobs running around assaulting people, burning things, and destroying monuments with government and police forces politically unable to stop them. 

At some point you have to either crack down hard for the sake of security and stability, or just throw up your hands and say, "We can't keep order. We can't enforce law. We can't do any of the things that a people expect a government to do. Let's divide the nation into parts and let them run themselves because The United States no longer exists". The alternative to those options is a civil war or anarchy, and those things will not be good for anyone.

And yes, if you catch a terrorist and he has information that can prevent another attack or destroy the terrorist group in question, put his fucking nuts in a toaster if that's what you have to do. It's not that too many laws or too much authority is inherently bad, but only when it isn't applied in a common sense way. IMO we've become too dependent on doing things by the book, and we no longer really do obvious things that would be best for the whole country.

You don't want a situation that is too authoritarian, but you absolutely can't have chaos. A lot more people die in situations where there are no rules than when there are too many rules. In most of these more authoritarian states you have nothing to worry about unless you're too many standard deviations outside the norm.

FWIW, I think the Iraq war with its expense, its lives lost, and the destabilization it caused in the Middle East did a lot more damage to the United States than the Patriot Act did.

parent.body:
We all collectively went mad for a while after 9/11. Everyone was so emotional that there were really only two thoughts in the "collective consciousness" of the nation: revenge and safety. Which was understandable. The issue was that our glorious leaders were allowed to draft legislation during that period of temporary insanity (and yeah, I think Dick Cheney is just evil and along with others there was certainly some nefarious intent behind the trashing of our rights). But while it was happening, most folks werent thinking about rights.  We were all too upset. When we woke up from it, a lot of conservatives wouldn't criticize it because it was "their guys" who enacted it. The same way you hear crickets on the left when you talk about Obama bombing civilians overseas. Its tribalism and pride. 

I think there should be a law about a "cooling off period" after a national disaster where they're not allowed to draft any new legislation until everyone calms down. 

So yeah. I agree witchu, but hindsight is 20/20 and at the time, very few people (myself included, though I wouldn't call myself a conservative) were able to master their emotions enough to really see it in the same way we see it now, 19 years later.

The same way you hear crickets on the left when you talk about Obama bombing civilians overseas. Its tribalism and pride.

I think there should be a law about a "cooling off period" after a national disaster where they're not allowed to draft any new legislation until everyone calms down.

So yeah. I agree witchu, but hindsight is 20/20 and at the time, very few people (myself included, though I wouldn't call myself a conservative) were able to master their emotions enough to really see it in the same way we see it now, 19 years later.

parent.body:
You took it on the chin for that comment, but I can see your point.

We're seeing now what happens when there are no restrictions or too few restrictions on liberties, with mobs running around assaulting people, burning things, and destroying monuments with government and police forces politically unable to stop them. 

At some point you have to either crack down hard for the sake of security and stability, or just throw up your hands and say, "We can't keep order. We can't enforce law. We can't do any of the things that a people expect a government to do. Let's divide the nation into parts and let them run themselves because The United States no longer exists". The alternative to those options is a civil war or anarchy, and those things will not be good for anyone.

And yes, if you catch a terrorist and he has information that can prevent another attack or destroy the terrorist group in question, put his fucking nuts in a toaster if that's what you have to do. It's not that too many laws or too much authority is inherently bad, but only when it isn't applied in a common sense way. IMO we've become too dependent on doing things by the book, and we no longer really do obvious things that would be best for the whole country.

You don't want a situation that is too authoritarian, but you absolutely can't have chaos. A lot more people die in situations where there are no rules than when there are too many rules. In most of these more authoritarian states you have nothing to worry about unless you're too many standard deviations outside the norm.

FWIW, I think the Iraq war with its expense, its lives lost, and the destabilization it caused in the Middle East did a lot more damage to the United States than the Patriot Act did.

parent.body:
We all collectively went mad for a while after 9/11. Everyone was so emotional that there were really only two thoughts in the "collective consciousness" of the nation: revenge and safety. Which was understandable. The issue was that our glorious leaders were allowed to draft legislation during that period of temporary insanity (and yeah, I think Dick Cheney is just evil and along with others there was certainly some nefarious intent behind the trashing of our rights). But while it was happening, most folks werent thinking about rights.  We were all too upset. When we woke up from it, a lot of conservatives wouldn't criticize it because it was "their guys" who enacted it. The same way you hear crickets on the left when you talk about Obama bombing civilians overseas. Its tribalism and pride. 

I think there should be a law about a "cooling off period" after a national disaster where they're not allowed to draft any new legislation until everyone calms down. 

So yeah. I agree witchu, but hindsight is 20/20 and at the time, very few people (myself included, though I wouldn't call myself a conservative) were able to master their emotions enough to really see it in the same way we see it now, 19 years later.

parent.body:
This is a very fair and accurate way to describe it. 

It is perhaps important to understand for those who were too young or not yet born at the time, nearly the entire nation was collectively in support of these actions at the time, even the public. You still hear people mentioning "post 9/11 unity" for a reason, literally the entire country as whole was looking the same direction, even politics were bipartisan and on the same page. 

Good case and point that supporting and passing legislation as an emotional reaction is not wise.

Then when the opposing side gains public sympathy, they go even farther than the side they profess to hate. That's what I especially hate about the Left's use of corporations to suppress Free Speech.  They're stupid enough to think the public good will will always be on their side and refuse to look down the line at what the Right could do by using the same tactics.

parent.body:
We all collectively went mad for a while after 9/11. Everyone was so emotional that there were really only two thoughts in the "collective consciousness" of the nation: revenge and safety. Which was understandable. The issue was that our glorious leaders were allowed to draft legislation during that period of temporary insanity (and yeah, I think Dick Cheney is just evil and along with others there was certainly some nefarious intent behind the trashing of our rights). But while it was happening, most folks werent thinking about rights.  We were all too upset. When we woke up from it, a lot of conservatives wouldn't criticize it because it was "their guys" who enacted it. The same way you hear crickets on the left when you talk about Obama bombing civilians overseas. Its tribalism and pride. 

I think there should be a law about a "cooling off period" after a national disaster where they're not allowed to draft any new legislation until everyone calms down. 

So yeah. I agree witchu, but hindsight is 20/20 and at the time, very few people (myself included, though I wouldn't call myself a conservative) were able to master their emotions enough to really see it in the same way we see it now, 19 years later.
